author: By Natasha Frost
title: Thursday Briefing
description: Concerns about Israel’s military objectives.
content: Skepticism is growing over one of Israel’s key objectives: to eliminate Hamas, the Islamist political and military organization that maintains control over the Gaza Strip. Increasingly, critics such as President Emmanuel Macron of France are questioning whether resolving to destroy such a deeply entrenched organization was ever realistic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron and Dana G. Smith
title: 10 Ways to Support Your Mental Health in 2024
description: These simple and proven strategies will help you manage stress and find meaning in the new year.
content: Since the height of the pandemic, there has been a cultural shift in the way we talk about mental health. It’s as though the years of isolation and uncertainty helped us understand how vital our emotional needs were to our overall well-being.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Alisha Jucevic
title: Snow Shortages Are Plaguing the West’s Mountains
description: Some ski areas remain closed. But an even greater concern amid a changing climate is whether enough snow will fall to meet water needs for the summer.
content: With gusts of wind howling around Mount Ashland’s vacant ski lodge this week, Andrew Gast watched from a window as a brief snowfall dusted the landscape. It was not nearly enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: 10 Nutrition Tips for a Healthy New Year
description: We’ve learned plenty about eating well. Here’s the advice we’ll carry with us into 2024.
content: As a health reporter who’s been following nutrition news for decades, I’ve seen a lot of trends that made a splash — and then sank. Remember olestra, the Paleo diet and celery juice?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘The Three Musketeers’ and the Joy of Old-School Blockbusters
description: With its practical effects and broad-minded approach to story, the French franchise revives the pleasures of earlier movie spectacles, but with a Gallic twist.
content: “The Three Musketeers” is to France what Mickey Mouse is to America — a cultural force with a lock on the country’s imagination. The 19th-century cloak-and-dagger tale, written by Alexandre Dumas, has lived countless lives onstage and onscreen, with stars, including Charlie Sheen, Charlton Heston, Milla Jovovich and even Barbie, resurrecting the classic tale of the Kings guard. It’s as iconically French as the Eiffel Tower, yet, until recently, it had been more than 60 years since the last French movie adaptation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval and Hamed Aleaziz
title: Justice Dept. Threatens to Sue Texas Over Migrant Arrest Law
description: In a letter addressed to Texas’ governor and attorney general, a D.O.J. official wrote that the federal government had sole authority over immigration enforcement.
content: The Justice Department on Thursday threatened to sue Texas if it enforced a sweeping new law that would allow the state and local police to arrest migrants who enter the United States from Mexico without authorization, setting up the first significant legal showdown over federal immigration enforcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William McDonald
title: In 2023, a Host of Consequential, and Very Long, Lives Lost
description: Life expectancy averages may be falling, but you might not have been able to tell that from reading the obituaries this year.
content: In February 1961, The New York Times, citing a study by the American Medical Association, ran a brief article reporting that Americans could very well enjoy a life expectancy of 120 years during the 21st century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Lauren Boebert, Far-Right Firebrand, Is Switching House Districts in Colorado
description: Facing a strong primary challenger and the fallout from the “Beetlejuice” scandal, Ms. Boebert is turning to a more conservative district in hopes of victory.
content: Representative Lauren Boebert, a far-right House Republican, announced on Wednesday that she would run in a more conservative district in Colorado — seeking to increase her chances after a strong primary challenger emerged in her district.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Pope.L, Provocative Performance Artist, Dies at 68
description: He is best known for crawling along the entirety of Broadway in Manhattan wearing a Superman costume, a work that blended satire and resistance.
content: Pope.L, an uncompromising conceptual and performance artist who explored themes of race, class and what he called “have-not-ness,” and who was best known for crawling the length of Broadway in a Superman costume, died on Saturday at his home in Chicago. He was 68.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Chess Federation Fines Player Over Her ‘Sports Shoes’
description: The Dutch chess player, who received an official warning, said she did not intend to violate the dress code when she wore her canvas Burberry sneakers at a chess championship in Uzbekistan.
content: The International Chess Federation fined a 23-year-old chess player from the Netherlands at its World Rapid and Blitz Championships in Samarkand, Uzbekistan, for wearing “sports shoes.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: The holidays are not everybody’s favorite time of year, I realize. There’s a lot of chaos and dashed expectations, and families can be complicated. Still: I have a soft spot for the season’s spirit, and a fond nostalgia for the extended break that swings, like a kid on a jungle gym, from Christmas or Hanukkah to New Year’s, leading us out of one thing and into the next, out of the past and into the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: 9 Ways to Improve Your Relationships in 2024
description: Pay a compliment, focus on the things you can control and, for goodness’ sake, put down your phone.
content: Small nuggets of advice can sometimes lead to big changes in relationships. My colleagues and I on the Well desk are fortunate to regularly interview psychotherapists, couples counselors, sex therapists and researchers who share their most useful tactics for strengthening connections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Laura Boushnak
title: Foreigners Who Made Ukraine Home Stay Put, Despite War
description: As millions fled, some expatriates made the unlikely decision to remain in Ukraine, among them students determined to finish their education and others who now consider it home.
content: It was just three months after the Russian invasion of Ukraine in early 2022, but Marwa Yehea wanted to return to her home in Kyiv.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Anat Schwartz, Adam Sella and Avishag Shaar-Yashuv
title: ‘Screams Without Words’: How Hamas Weaponized Sexual Violence on Oct. 7
description: A Times investigation uncovered new details showing a pattern of rape, mutilation and extreme brutality against women in the attacks on Israel.
content: At first, she was known simply as “the woman in the black dress.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: Home Prices Grew, but Mobile Home Prices Grew Faster
description: Census data reveals the extraordinary growth of manufactured home prices since 2017.
content: Manufactured homes have traditionally offered a more affordable option for home buyers in a housing market that has few such options. And they still do, but in recent years, the prices of manufactured homes — usually called mobile homes — have been rising faster than those of traditionally-built single-family homes, according to a study by LendingTree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: ‘Significant Damage’ Reported as Storm Moves Through Britain
description: Strong winds and heavy rain are expected in England over the coming days, according to forecasters.
content: A powerful storm bringing strong, gusty winds as it moves across Britain has left thousands of customers in Wales and England without power, delivered heavy rain and flood warnings, and disrupted train journeys ahead of the long New Year’s weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Apple Resuming Sales of Its Newest Smartwatches, for Now
description: The company pulled two watches from stores after losing a patent case, but an appeals court temporarily paused enforcement of that ruling while the legal battle continues.
content: Apple resumed sales of its newest smartwatches on Thursday, a day after a federal appeals court temporarily reversed an earlier ban on their import and sale in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Primaries, Polls and Party Shares: It’s Time for the Mailbag.
description: Readers have questions, including on switching over to another side’s primary, and a quick comment on Swift.
content: I hope everyone is enjoying the holiday season. We haven’t received many questions about the Republican primary recently, even though the Iowa Caucus is less than three weeks away. But we have gotten a few, and many on other topics, so let’s dive into the mailbox one last time in 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: 2023’s Greatest Hits and Veggie Resolutions
description: We all did an especially good job with breakfast — bircher muesli, breakfast burritos and a cheesy spinach casserole were big hits.
content: Few things cause whiplash quite like the list of things you resolved to accomplish a year ago, written in a postholiday haze of euphoria and optimism. Around this time last year, I outlined my own 2023 kitchen resolutions in this very newsletter. I resolved to cut down on restaurant meals, stop skipping breakfast and cook one new recipe from a cookbook each week. I asked you to share your own resolutions with me and said we’d “see how we did a year from now.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Bill Granger, Chef Who Brought Avocado Toast to the World, Dies at 54
description: His breakfast cuisine catapulted Australian cafe culture to international acclaim, although some saw his best-known dish as an example of millennial excess.
content: Bill Granger, a chef who combined an easy Australian manner with a talent for making simple food sing, selling the world on the infinite potential of breakfast, died on Christmas Day in London. He was 54.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 28, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Dec. 28, 2023.
content: An article on Tuesday about talks expected on Tuesday between Ron Dermer, Israel’s minister of strategic affairs, and U.S. officials incorrectly attributed information about the expected content of the talks. It was an Israeli official who said the talks were expected to focus on the next phase of the war and postwar Gaza; it was not Adrienne Watson, the National Security Council spokeswoman who confirmed that the talks were scheduled for Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Opinion
title: Let’s Talk 2023: Opinion Writers Respond to Your Comments
description: Opinion looks back at some of the most engaging comment threads of 2023.
content: Each week, readers submit thousands of comments on Opinion pieces. The word “appreciation” doesn’t begin to cover how our staff feels about them. Comments can challenge, gratify, inspire and anger us — sometimes all at once. They make us strive to do better.We recently reviewed some of the most engaging comment sections we’ve experienced this year (so far!) and decided we had to pay tribute. So we asked the authors of some of the relevant pieces to respond to what readers had to say. We hope you enjoy looking back at these conversations as much as we did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning and Anjali Huynh
title: Young Iowa Republicans Raise Their Voices. Will Their Party Listen?
description: G.O.P. presidential candidates have not aggressively courted Gen Z, even as young voters increasingly show an openness to new candidates and a concern for new ideas.
content: As Vivek Ramaswamy walked out of an event this month at Dordt University, a small Christian college in northwestern Iowa, the school’s football players greeted him with bro hugs and a challenge: Could he join one of them in doing 30 push-ups?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Jazmine Ulloa
title: When Haley Dodged the Slavery Question, She Put Her Coalition at Risk
description: Nikki Haley’s avoidance of mentioning slavery as a cause of the conflict, which she walked back on Thursday, threatened to dent her crossover appeal to independents and moderate Democrats.
content: Prominent Democratic donors, anxious about the increasingly authoritarian language of Donald J. Trump, have been calling on Democratic voters and independents to thwart the former president’s comeback by voting for Nikki Haley in open Republican primary elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudia Gryvatz Copquin and Jill P. Capuzzo
title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: This week’s properties are a three-bedroom in Locust Valley, N.Y., and a five-bedroom in Medford Lakes, N.J.
content: A three-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath house built in 1908 with a foyer, a living room with a gas fireplace, a dining room with a wood-burning fireplace, a sunroom/office and a breakfast room with skylights, an unfinished partial basement and a rear deck, on 0.16 acres. Kimberly Bancroft, Daniel Gale Sotheby’s International Realty, 516-404-5053; danielgale.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Israeli-American Thought to Be a Hostage Was Killed on Oct. 7, Her Family Says
description: The bodies of Judih Weinstein Haggai and her husband, Gadi Haggai, are still held by Hamas, their family said.
content: Judih Weinstein Haggai, a 70-year-old who was believed to have been taken hostage by Hamas, was actually killed during the Oct. 7 attacks on Israel, her family and Kibbutz Nir Oz said in statements on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: A.I. Can Make Art That Feels Human. Whose Fault Is That?
description: A fake Drake/Weeknd mash-up is not a threat to our species’s culture. It’s a warning: We can’t let our imaginations shrink to machine size.
content: This was the year — ask your stockbroker, or the disgraced management of Sports Illustrated — that artificial intelligence went from a dreamy projection to an ambient menace and perpetual sales pitch. Does it feel like the future to you, or has A.I. already taken on the staleness and scamminess of the now-worthless nonfungible token?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mira Jacob
title: Things I Thought Made Sense Just Don’t Anymore
description: Most days I feel as if I woke up from a nap I didn’t mean to take into a world I don’t quite recognize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Rosenberg
title: Botticelli, Beyond the Renaissance
description: Viewers gravitate to his astonishingly tender paintings, but at the Legion of Honor, his preparatory drawings offer a view of a gifted master of line.
content: As the largest loan exhibition of Botticelli in the United States to date, “Botticelli Drawings,” at the Legion of Honor, sounds at first like a celebration of a Renaissance talent on the order of the Metropolitan Museum’s celebration of Michelangelo’s drawings from a few years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By the staff of The Morning
title: The Year’s Best Times Opinion Coverage
description: A selection of columns, essays and videos chosen by the department’s editors.
content: We’re using today’s newsletter to highlight a selection of the best Times Opinion coverage of the year, as chosen by the department’s editors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: A Pint of Wine? Britain Plans to Bring Back an Old-Fashioned Measure.
description: Boris Johnson called the use of imperial measurements “an ancient liberty” and pledged to bring them back after Brexit. The public didn’t want that, so the government settled for pint-size wine.
content: In 2024, the Brits will be able to drink like Winston Churchill again.
source.name: The New York Times

title: T Magazine’s Favorite Food Stories of 2023
description: Holiday canapés, essential dishes to eat around the world — and more.
content: For this week’s edition of the T List, we’re looking back on the dishes and food trends we featured this year, from our lists of the 25 essential plates to try in Mexico City and Paris to recipes for professional-chef-approved holiday hors d’oeuvres. We hope the pieces below might inspire your own projects in the kitchen, or your 2024 travel plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: How Columbia’s President Has Avoided Fallout Over Israel-Gaza Protests
description: Protests over the Israel-Hamas war roiled Columbia’s campus for weeks. Then, the campus and its president receded from attention — for now.
content: In the weeks after Oct. 7, Columbia University was the scene of rising tensions over the Israel-Hamas war on American college campuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Boeing Urges Airlines to Inspect 737 Max Planes for Possible Loose Bolts
description: The F.A.A. said it was monitoring inspections after an airline discovered a bolt with a missing nut in the plane’s rudder-control system.
content: Boeing has urged airlines to inspect all 737 Max airplanes for a possible loose bolt in the rudder-control system after an international airline discovered a bolt with a missing nut while performing routine maintenance, the Federal Aviation Administration said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Arlo Brown
title: How Cancer Has Influenced, but Not Controlled, a Musician’s Work
description: “The music stays as beautiful as it is,” said Andreas Staier, an eminent interpreter of early keyboard music who has a rare blood disease.
content: The harpsichordist and pianist Andreas Staier has never been a morning person. And since August 2019, when he was diagnosed with primary myelofibrosis, a rare bone marrow cancer, he has felt what he called a fundamental fear most vividly in the mornings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: Criticize This African Country’s Army and You Might Be Drafted
description: The military junta in Burkina Faso, a West African nation struggling to defeat extremist groups, has been forcibly conscripting critics, say human rights organizations.
content: One Friday earlier this month, just as Dr. Daouda Diallo stepped out of the passport office in the capital of the West African nation of Burkina Faso, four men grabbed him off the street, pushed him into a vehicle and drove off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: ‘Almost Naked’ Party in Moscow Angers Russian Conservatives
description: Outrage over scantily clad socialites highlights the growing contradictions of a society reshaped by the war in Ukraine.
content: Tearful apologies, revoked sponsorships, canceled performances and two weeks in jail for wearing a sock on the genitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Death of ‘Parasite’ Star Highlights South Korea’s Crackdown on Drugs
description: The actor, Lee Sun-kyun, had been questioned on suspicion of drug use in a country that has long drawn a hard line against anything other than total abstinence.
content: Lee Sun-kyun, the “Parasite” actor who was found dead on Wednesday, was far from the only celebrity entangled in South Korea’s latest antidrug crackdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Herbert Kohl, Former Wisconsin Senator and Milwaukee Bucks Owner, Dies at 88
description: A member of the family that founded Kohl’s department stores, he guarded federal budgets as a U.S. senator while spending lavishly to revive the N.B.A. team he owned.
content: Herbert H. Kohl, a Wisconsin Democrat who kept watch over federal budgets in four terms as a United States senator, but who as the die-hard owner of the National Basketball Association’s often mediocre Milwaukee Bucks spent lavishly to keep the team afloat in his hometown, died on Wednesday afternoon at his home in Milwaukee. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Jordan
title: The Novel That Sold 1,000 Copies a Week in 1903
description: Mary Augusta Ward’s “Lady Rose’s Daughter” was the blockbuster best seller of its day.
content: At the turn of the 20th century, the Book Review regularly ran an article called “Books in Demand,” which was a list of the most checked-out books at the New York Public Library (and in many ways a precursor of our best-seller lists).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Dan Simmons
title: University Chancellor Fired After Making Pornographic Videos With His Wife
description: The University of Wisconsin System’s top official said she was “disgusted” by the chancellor’s actions; the chancellor says he was exercising his right to free speech.
content: The chancellor of a state university in Wisconsin was fired this week after posting pornographic videos with his wife online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Four Seasons in One Day
description: Kiran Pandey loves the movies.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: Crews Demolish Site of Idaho Murders as Some Families Object
description: The University of Idaho moved ahead with plans to tear down an off-campus house where four students were murdered last year.
content: Demolition crews have torn down a house near the University of Idaho where four college students were murdered last year. The removal comes despite objections from some family members of the victims who believe the site should be preserved in case it is needed for a future trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Caitlin O'Keefe
title: In a Song of the Summer, Clues for January in Iowa
description: Jason Aldean’s single “Try That in a Small Town” stirred up political controversy, and climbed the charts. We talked to Aldean fans about what they heard in the song.
content: Last summer, politics, country music and cultural grievance collided with the growing popularity of a new song from recording artist Jason Aldean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Friday Briefing: A Pattern of Rape and Torture on Oct. 7
description: Also, migration to the U.S. and the threat to art from A.I.
content: Israeli officials say that everywhere Hamas terrorists struck on Oct. 7 — a rave, military bases along the Gaza border and kibbutz after kibbutz — they brutalized women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Classic Wedding Traditions Find a New Groove
description: Some time-honored customs have been reimagined for modern brides and grooms seeking a touch of nostalgia with a contemporary twist.
content: While some tried and true wedding traditions may have lost their luster, wedding professionals are taking note of modern iterations that honor and elevate classic trends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: ‘I Feel Like I Don’t Matter’: East Palestine Waits for a Presidential Visit
description: The White House has said that Mr. Biden still plans to visit the site of a toxic derailment in February. But his absence feels like disrespect to many people in East Palestine, Ohio.
content: When Jessica Conard heard that President Biden would visit her community in East Palestine, she felt a sense of relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clair MacDougall and Emma Bubola
title: Gas Tanker Explosion Kills More Than 40 in Liberia
description: After the tanker overturned in an accident, people gathered around the vehicle trying to scoop up fuel before it caught fire and exploded.
content: Dozens of people were killed on a roadside in Liberia after they rushed to scoop up fuel from an overturned tanker before it exploded, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Sydney Harper, Carlos Prieto, Nina Feldman, Clare Toeniskoetter, M.J. Davis Lin, Patricia Willens, Lisa Chow, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Brad Fisher and Chris Wood
title: A Mother, a Daughter, a Deadly Journey: An Update
description: An increasing number of migrants are trying to pass through the dangerous terrain connecting South and Central America. What forces them to take that route?
content: This week, The Daily is revisiting some of our favorite episodes of the year and checking in on what has happened in the time since they first ran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: The Sidney Awards
description: Some of the best long-form essays of 2023.
content: If you want to help people, there are many fine causes you can donate to. If you want to change the world, support a small magazine. It’s hard to imagine the Progressive era or the New Deal without a small magazine, The New Republic. There probably would have been no Reagan revolution without another small magazine, National Review. The Partisan Review had a circulation of roughly 5,000 to 7,000 at its peak but set the tone for America’s postwar intellectual life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nell Scovell
title: Simpleton? Genius? Who was Tom Smothers?
description: He was close with John Lennon, and had a sophisticated understanding of wine, politics and literature. He only played the bumpkin onstage.
content: I read the news today, oh boy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: These Bejeweled Treats Are a Must for Three Kings Day
description: Mexican bakeries on both sides of the border begin making rosca de reyes, three kings bread, weeks in advance.
content: Mexican bakeries begin their preparations for Día de los Reyes Magos, or Three Kings Day, weeks before the holiday’s Jan. 6 arrival. At La Monarca Bakery & Cafe in Los Angeles, bakers have been mixing and freezing bread dough since early December for the celebration’s signature treat: rosca de reyes, or three kings bread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fu and Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: How China’s Property Crisis Blew Up Bets That Couldn’t Lose
description: Citic said its new fund was as safe as they come because it would invest in real estate. Then the developer defaulted and the projects stalled.
content: One of China’s largest investment firms, Citic Trust, had a clear pitch to investors when it was aiming to raise $1.7 billion to fund property development in 2020: There is no safer Chinese investment than real estate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: Put Potato Chips on Your Potato Tart
description: And supersize your almond croissant.
content: “I put potato chips on the potato tart because, why not?” It doesn’t take a lot for Melissa Clark to sell us on a new recipe — she is Melissa Clark, after all — but when she said that bit about her new crispy potato and sour cream tart to the New York Times Cooking team, we were all very much on board. For this surprisingly easy tart, sliced cooked potatoes are folded into a lush mix of sour cream, Parmesan and chives, then spread onto a (store-bought) puff pastry crust.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Confederate Monument Is Taken Down in Florida
description: Discussion about removing the “Tribute to the Women of the Southern Confederacy” memorial in Jacksonville started in 2020, after the killing of George Floyd.
content: A Confederate monument was taken down in Jacksonville, Fla., on Wednesday, after an order by the city’s mayor ended years of debate, as officials around the United States reckon with memorials on public property that commemorate the Confederacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: The Best Sentences of 2023
description: Here are dozens of journalism’s gems from a year when we badly needed them.
content: Over recent days, I took on a daunting task — but a delightful one. I reviewed all the passages of prose featured in the For the Love of Sentences section of my Times Opinion newsletter in 2023 and tried to determine the best of the best. And there’s no doing that, at least not objectively, not when the harvest is so bountiful.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
description: Surveys of works by Helvi Leiviska and Louis Wayne Ballard, as well as a restored version of “Cavalleria Rusticana,” are among the highlights.
content: Earlier this year, Bis, the essential Swedish label that has brought us Osmo Vanska’s Beethoven, Masaaki Suzuki’s Bach and every score that Jean Sibelius ever wrote, celebrated its 50th anniversary by announcing that it had sold itself to Apple. Coming not long after Universal had acquired Hyperion, as well as a significant stake in the parent company of Harmonia Mundi, the news felt grim. Those labels had not just been independent in ownership, but also independent in spirit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Yasmin Marikar
title: He’s Been Hiding Celebrities Since 2007
description: With haunts like The Bird Streets, Bootsy Bellows and Delilah, John Terzian is the rare club owner that famous people trust. But when everyone is a paparazzo, how does he keep a secret?
content: Going out, once a hallmark of celebrity status, took a hit this past year. Amid entertainment industry strikes and global turmoil, it seemed like many of the folks who formerly sought to see and be seen threw on sweats and stayed in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
description: This week’s properties are in Lenox Hill, NoMad and Fort Greene.
content: A one-bath, 547-square-foot, newly updated studio with a large foyer or dining area, a Murphy bed, built-ins and a marble bathroom on the 17th floor of a 31-story doorman building with a concierge, live-in super, gym, catering room, children’s playroom and shared laundry. Joshua Garner and Mike Fabbri, The Agency, 203-535-4554; theagencyre.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilyssa Daly, Jerry Mitchell, Rachel Axon and Rory Doyle for The New York Times
title: Who Investigates the Sheriff? In Mississippi, Often No One.
description: The state ignored or was unaware of allegations of jailhouse rape, brutal beatings and corrupt acts by sheriffs and their deputies, even when there was ample evidence to examine.
content: As Marquise Tillman led deputies on a high-speed chase through rural Mississippi in March 2019, Sheriff Todd Kemp issued a blunt order over the radio: “Shut him down and beat his ass.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: The State of Deals
description: Next year’s biggest headwinds for deal making will be “geopolitics, geopolitics and geopolitics,” says Viswas Raghavan, the co-head of global investment banking at JPMorgan Chase.
content: For deal makers, 2024 is a year to look forward to, if only because 2023 wasn’t necessarily one to celebrate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Walker Mimms
title: William Blake’s Prints Tapped the Power of a Wild Mind
description: A crackling collection of experimental prints by William Blake resurrects the English poet-painter in all his radical frenzy, and foretells the limits of political art.
content: “A wild pet for the supercultivated,” as T.S. Eliot called him, is only half the story of William Blake (1757-1827), a poet who is more famous for his influence on certain moderns (Allen Ginsberg, Bob Dylan, Patti Smith) than actually read.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Supreme Court and Donald Trump
description: Readers discuss a guest essay that argued it would be a mistake to keep the former president off the ballot. Also: Political despair; nonelite colleges; dinners with Churchill.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Nazaryan
title: A Hopeful Reminder: You’re Going to Die
description: Fifty years on, Ernest Becker’s “The Denial of Death” remains an essential, surprisingly upbeat guide to our final act on Earth.
content: Ernest Becker was already dying when “The Denial of Death” was published 50 years ago this past fall. “This is a test of everything I’ve written about death,” he told a visitor to his Vancouver hospital room. Throughout his career as a cultural anthropologist, Becker had charted the undiscovered country that awaits us all. Now only 49 but losing a battle to colon cancer, he was being dispatched there himself. By the time his book was awarded a Pulitzer Prize the following spring, Becker was gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Haley, Asked About the Cause of the Civil War, Avoids Mentioning Slavery
description: A pointed question, at a town hall in New Hampshire, raises a complicated topic for Nikki Haley, who as governor of South Carolina wrestled with issues stemming from the Confederacy.
content: Nikki Haley, the Republican presidential candidate and former governor of South Carolina who for years has wrestled with how to approach issues of race, slavery and the Confederacy, found herself again confronted with those subjects at a town hall event on Wednesday in New Hampshire, hundreds of miles north of the Mason-Dixon line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Russia Retakes Some Land Hard Won by Ukraine During Counteroffensive
description: Russia’s recent progress around the southern village of Robotyne is a sobering development for Ukraine amid dwindling Western military aid.
content: Russia has recaptured land hard won by Ukrainian troops at the peak of their summer counteroffensive in the south, making progress around the southern village of Robotyne.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: The 2023 High School Yearbook of American Politics
description: The most problematic nepo baby, the most fabulous fabulist, the most likely to be picked last in gym class and more.
content: It has been such a special political year, brimming with extraordinary, even historic moments. From an ex-president indicted to a Senate staffer busted for making porn at work, each fresh development made you proud to be an American.
source.name: The New York Times

title: David Mamet Names the Books That Explain the Real Hollywood
description: “One must read between the lies,” he suggests, putting his own “Everywhere an Oink Oink” at the top of the list.
content: What’s the last great book you read?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadav Gavrielov and Thomas Fuller
title: Israel Warns That Time for Diplomacy With Lebanon Is ‘Running Out’
description: As rockets from Iranian-backed Hezbollah forces streamed in from Lebanon, Israeli officials said they were prepared to take the war to a second front.
content: As Israel pounded targets in the Gaza Strip from the air and sea on Wednesday, a member of the country’s war cabinet threatened action on a second front, along the border with Lebanon, where the Iranian-backed militia Hezbollah has fired rocket barrages into Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King and Emily Cochrane
title: Federal Judge Approves Georgia’s New Voting Maps
description: The judge found that the Georgia legislature had complied with orders to allow Black voters an equal opportunity to elect representatives of their choice.
content: A federal judge on Thursday ruled that the Georgia legislature had complied with orders to draw voting maps that allowed Black voters an equal opportunity to elect representatives of their choice, signing off on new districts created earlier this month.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Moviegoers Tuned Out Spectacle in 2023
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 28, 2023.
content: “Moviegoers seem less interested in being overwhelmed with spectacle and saving the universe than being spoken to, entertained and inspired.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Lewis
title: Jacques Delors, Passionate Architect of European Unity, Dies at 98
description: As the executive of the European Union for a decade, he oversaw its increasing economic integration and led the drive for a single currency, the euro.
content: Jacques Delors, a hard-driving French politician who as the European Union’s executive for a decade became the chief architect of a more unified Europe and the father of Europe’s common currency, the euro, died on Wednesday at his home in Paris. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Petrow
title: I Promised My Sister I Would Write About How She Chose to Die
description: Medical aid in dying gave my sister a choice about how her life ended.
content: On the day before my sister Julie died, I lay down on her bed and held her gingerly in my arms, afraid that any pressure would hurt her. She had lost so much weight that she looked like a stick figure I might have drawn when we were kids. As her body had wasted, her tumors had grown — now several of them bigger than baseballs. Her abdomen looked like the lunar landscape, with protrusions everywhere, the sources of her pain plainly visible.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Staffers at The Times on the Books They Enjoyed in 2023
description: A 1960s crime caper, a biography of the man who created the modern F.B.I., Sinead O’Connor’s memoir: Reporters, writers, editors and bureau chiefs describe their favorite reads of the year.
content: Between our 100 Notable Books and 10 Best Books lists, we at The New York Times Book Review have had enough to say about the year in books. (And our readers had a lot to say about both of those lists!) So, to end 2023, we reached out to a few people across our newsroom to find out what books — new and old — they most enjoyed reading this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Curtis, Larissa Anderson and Daniel Ramirez
title: The Words That Lingered
description: Our book critics discuss the passages that stuck with them in 2023
content: Book critics Alexandra Jacobs, Jennifer Szalai and Dwight Garner have read thousands upon thousands of words this year, and out of everything they’ve read, these are the passages they can’t stop thinking about.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caity Weaver
title: When Being a Spokeswoman Attracts Leering Internet Trolls
description: When you lend your likeness to a nationwide ad campaign, things don’t always go perfectly. Just ask Milana Vayntrub.
content: Our ability to influence how others react to us is finite. We can devise slight physical modifications, but the most conspicuous aspects of our appearance (skeleton size, vigor of melanin production) remain largely fixed. We can design our own behavior but make only educated guesses as to how it will be received.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emilia Petrarca
title: A Holiday Celebration Inspired by Old New York
description: The Old Stone Trade founder Melissa Ventosa Martin and the One Of designer Patricia Voto channeled the Gilded Age to fete their evening-wear collaboration.
content: When Melissa Ventosa Martin, the founder of the online marketplace Old Stone Trade, and Patricia Voto, the designer and founder of the women’s wear line One Of, were introduced by a mutual client this past spring, the two felt an instant kinship. “I immediately DMed her on Instagram — very professional,” said Ventosa Martin, a stylist, creative consultant and former magazine editor whose three-year-old retail platform highlights handmade clothing and accessories from artisans around the globe. Soon after, Voto, 35, whose designs are all made to measure, invited Ventosa Martin, 44, to her New York apartment and, within that first visit, they’d come up with a plan for both an evening wear collaboration and an over-the-top launch party that would double as a holiday celebration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: San Francisco’s Montgomery Street Could Signal a Downtown Revival
description: From the revamped Transamerica Pyramid to a small public radio station broadcasting from a former copy shop, the street offers hope for recovery in the city.
content: It seemed like the last place one might invest a billion dollars on an office building in October 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Hamas weaponized sexual violence on Oct. 7
description: Plus, failing to prevent child labor.
content: A two-month investigation by The New York Times has uncovered painful new details about a pattern of rape, mutilation and extreme brutality used against Israeli women during the attacks by Hamas in early October. Sexual attacks against women were not isolated events but part of a broader pattern of gender-based violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: What to Watch This Weekend: Comedy Morsels Galore
description: The holiday season means an overcommitted social calendar and low-commitment viewing. Our TV critic has several great suggestions.
content: If the traditional Christmas meal is a feast, the traditional New Year’s Eve fare is hors d’oeuvres. To that end, this weekend is all about tidbits, the only kind of viewing that fits during a time of both busyness and vacantness, of being both off and on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Arsonist Ordered to Pay Nearly $300,000 for Damages to Wyoming Abortion Clinic
description: A woman serving a five-year sentence for setting fire to an abortion clinic in Casper, Wyo., in 2022 has been ordered to pay restitution to the clinic and its insurance company.
content: A federal judge has ordered a woman serving a five-year sentence for setting fire to an abortion clinic in Wyoming last year to pay nearly $300,000 in restitution, according to documents filed in the U.S. District Court in Wyoming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Berreby
title: ChatGPT Helps, and Worries, Business Consultants, Study Finds
description: The A.I. tool helped most with creative tasks. With more analytical work, however, the technology led to more mistakes.
content: Last spring, when Karim Lakhani began testing how ChatGPT affected the work of elite business consultants, he thought they’d be delighted by the tool. In a preliminary study of two dozen workers, the language bot had helped them finish two hours’ worth of tasks in 20 minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Urged to Move Fast on Trump’s Ballot Eligibility
description: The Colorado Republican Party asked the justices to decide its appeal by Super Tuesday. The voters who won in the Colorado Supreme Court want to move even faster.
content: The Supreme Court was asked on Thursday to fast-track its review of the stunning Colorado Supreme Court ruling that former President Donald J. Trump was ineligible to appear on the state’s primary ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: The Building Spree That Reshaped Manhattan’s Skyline? It’s Over.
description: New office buildings flourished over the past 25 years in Manhattan, but a construction drought has begun.
content: The Manhattan office construction boom is over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis and Mark Abramson
title: California Pushes Electric Trucks as the Future of Freight
description: A mainstay of cargo transport will be phased out at ports as California bans new registrations of carbon-fuel trucks in favor of nonpolluting ones.
content: Neri Diaz thought he was ready for a crucial juncture in California’s ambitious plans, closely watched in other states and around the world, to phase out diesel-powered trucks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Dreier
title: They’re Paid Billions to Root Out Child Labor in the U.S. Why Do They Fail?
description: Private auditors have failed to detect migrant children working for U.S. suppliers of Oreos, Gerber baby snacks, McDonald’s milk and many other products.
content: One morning in 2019, an auditor arrived at a meatpacking plant in rural Minnesota. He was there on behalf of the national drugstore chain Walgreens to ensure that the factory, which made the company’s house brand of beef jerky, was safe and free of labor abuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Amanda Holpuch
title: Gypsy Rose Blanchard Is Released From Prison in Missouri
description: In 2016, she was found guilty of helping to kill her mother in a murder that inspired an HBO documentary and a Hulu miniseries.
content: Gypsy Rose Blanchard, who was found guilty of helping to kill her abusive mother in a murder that inspired an HBO documentary and a Hulu miniseries, was released from prison on Thursday, the authorities in Missouri said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Our Keepers of 2023
description: The 55 things we watched, read, listened to, learned from, ate and laughed at in 2023 that will go with us into the new year.
content: The 55 things we watched, read, listened to, learned from, ate and laughed at in 2023 that will go with us into the new year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Singhvi, Bora Erden, Abu Bakr Bashir, Mika Gröndahl, Helmuth Rosales, Rumsey Taylor and Josh Williams
title: What Happened in One of Israel’s Deadliest Attacks in Gaza
description: In this airstrike, Israel was targeting a senior Hamas leader. Dozens of people in a residential neighborhood were killed in the attack.
content: In this airstrike, Israel was targeting a senior Hamas leader. Dozens of people in a residential neighborhood were killed in the attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: 36 Hours in Hong Kong
description: Experience the incense-filled neighborhoods, thought-provoking art and hilltop views of this glittering, international metropolis at a moment of deep political transformation.
content: Experience the incense-filled neighborhoods, thought-provoking art and hilltop views of this glittering, international metropolis at a moment of deep political transformation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eli Murray, Hannah Dreier and K.K. Rebecca Lai
title: Where Migrant Children Are Living, and Often Working, in the U.S.
description: Data shows where a record number of unaccompanied children traveling to the U.S. from Central America and other countries have ended up.
content: Data shows where a record number of unaccompanied children traveling to the U.S. from Central America and other countries have ended up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colette Coleman
title: Suddenly Single, He Took His $200,000 Budget Up to the Bronx. Would It Be Enough?
description: After an unexpected breakup, a college professor explored the co-ops of Riverdale and Spuyten Duyvil. Here’s where he landed.
content: After an unexpected breakup, a college professor explored the co-ops of Riverdale and Spuyten Duyvil. Here’s where he landed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Rattner and Taylor Maggiacomo
title: More Than Words: 10 Charts That Defined 2023
description: Ten charts to recap the trends and main events of 2023.
content: Ten charts to recap the trends and main events of 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanner Curtis, Karen Hanley, Elizabeth Pierson and Jeffrey Henson Scales
title: A Closer Look at the Year in Pictures
description: The Year in Pictures is a way to commemorate the big news events from January to December: the ones that traumatized us — and there are many — mixed with some moments of bliss.
content: The Year in Pictures is a way to commemorate the big news events from January to December: the ones that traumatized us — and there are many — mixed with some moments of bliss.
source.name: The New York Times
